segment.source: ListView and GridView data virtualization
segment.target: ListView and GridView data virtualization

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Note For more details, see the //build/ session Dramatically Increase Performance when Users Interact with Large Amounts of Data in GridView and ListView.
segment.target: Note For more details, see the //build/ session Dramatically Increase Performance when Users Interact with Large Amounts of Data in GridView and ListView.

segment.source: Improve ListView and GridView performance and startup time through data virtualization.
segment.target: Improve ListView and GridView performance and startup time through data virtualization.

segment.source: For UI virtualization, element reduction, and progressive updating of items, see ListView and GridView UI optimization.
segment.target: For UI virtualization, element reduction, and progressive updating of items, see ListView and GridView UI optimization.

segment.source: A method of data virtualization is needed for a data set that is so large that it cannot or should not all be stored in memory at one time.
segment.target: A method of data virtualization is needed for a data set that is so large that it cannot or should not all be stored in memory at one time.

segment.source: You load an initial portion into memory (from local disk, network, or cloud) and apply UI virtualization to this partial data set.
segment.target: You load an initial portion into memory (from local disk, network, or cloud) and apply UI virtualization to this partial data set.

segment.source: You can later load data incrementally, or from arbitrary points in the master data set (random access), on demand.
segment.target: You can later load data incrementally, or from arbitrary points in the master data set (random access), on demand.

segment.source: Whether data virtualization is appropriate for you depends on many factors.
segment.target: Whether data virtualization is appropriate for you depends on many factors.

segment.source: The size of your data set
segment.target: The size of your data set

segment.source: The size of each item
segment.target: The size of each item

segment.source: The source of the data set (local disk, network, or cloud)
segment.target: The source of the data set (local disk, network, or cloud)

segment.source: The overall memory consumption of your app
segment.target: The overall memory consumption of your app

segment.source: Note Be aware that a feature is enabled by default for ListView and GridView that displays temporary placeholder visuals while the user is panning/scrolling quickly.
segment.target: Note Be aware that a feature is enabled by default for ListView and GridView that displays temporary placeholder visuals while the user is panning/scrolling quickly.

segment.source: As data is loaded, these placeholder visuals are replaced with your item template.
segment.target: As data is loaded, these placeholder visuals are replaced with your item template.

segment.source: You can turn the feature off by setting ListViewBase.ShowsScrollingPlaceholders to false, but if you do so then we recommend that you use the x:Phase attribute to progressively render the elements in your item template.
segment.target: You can turn the feature off by setting ListViewBase.ShowsScrollingPlaceholders to false, but if you do so then we recommend that you use the x:Phase attribute to progressively render the elements in your item template.

segment.source: See Update ListView and GridView items progressively.
segment.target: See Update ListView and GridView items progressively.

segment.source: Here are more details about the incremental and random-access data virtualization techniques.
segment.target: Here are more details about the incremental and random-access data virtualization techniques.

segment.source: Incremental data virtualization
segment.target: Incremental data virtualization

segment.source: Incremental data virtualization loads data sequentially.
segment.target: Incremental data virtualization loads data sequentially.

segment.source: A ListView that uses incremental data virtualization may be used to view a collection of a million items, but only 50 items are loaded initially.
segment.target: A ListView that uses incremental data virtualization may be used to view a collection of a million items, but only 50 items are loaded initially.

segment.source: As the user pans/scrolls, the next 50 are loaded.
segment.target: As the user pans/scrolls, the next 50 are loaded.

segment.source: As items are loaded, the scroll bar's thumb decreases in size.
segment.target: As items are loaded, the scroll bar's thumb decreases in size.

segment.source: For this type of data virtualization you write a data source class that implements these interfaces.
segment.target: For this type of data virtualization you write a data source class that implements these interfaces.

segment.source: IList
segment.target: IList

segment.source: INotifyCollectionChanged (C\#/VB) or IObservableVectorT (C++/CX)
segment.target: INotifyCollectionChanged (C\#/VB) or IObservableVectorT (C++/CX)

segment.source: ISupportIncrementalLoading
segment.target: ISupportIncrementalLoading

segment.source: A data source like this is an in-memory list that can be continually extended.
segment.target: A data source like this is an in-memory list that can be continually extended.

segment.source: The items control will ask for items using the standard IList indexer and count properties.
segment.target: The items control will ask for items using the standard IList indexer and count properties.

segment.source: The count should represent the number of items locally, not the true size of the dataset.
segment.target: The count should represent the number of items locally, not the true size of the dataset.

segment.source: When the items control gets close to the end of the existing data, it will call ISupportIncrementalLoading.HasMoreItems.
segment.target: When the items control gets close to the end of the existing data, it will call ISupportIncrementalLoading.HasMoreItems.

segment.source: If you return true, then it will call ISupportIncrementalLoading.LoadMoreItemsAsync passing an advised number of items to load.
segment.target: If you return true, then it will call ISupportIncrementalLoading.LoadMoreItemsAsync passing an advised number of items to load.

segment.source: Depending on where you're loading data from (local disk, network, or cloud), you may choose to load a different number of items than that advised.
segment.target: Depending on where you're loading data from (local disk, network, or cloud), you may choose to load a different number of items than that advised.

segment.source: For example, if your service supports batches of 50 items but the items control only asks for 10 then you can load 50.
segment.target: For example, if your service supports batches of 50 items but the items control only asks for 10 then you can load 50.

segment.source: Load the data from your back end, add it to your list, and raise a change notification via INotifyCollectionChanged or IObservableVectorT so that the items control knows about the new items.
segment.target: Load the data from your back end, add it to your list, and raise a change notification via INotifyCollectionChanged or IObservableVectorT so that the items control knows about the new items.

segment.source: Also return a count of the items you actually loaded.
segment.target: Also return a count of the items you actually loaded.

segment.source: If you load fewer items than advised, or the items control has been panned/scrolled even further in the interim, then your data source will be called again for more items and the cycle will continue.
segment.target: If you load fewer items than advised, or the items control has been panned/scrolled even further in the interim, then your data source will be called again for more items and the cycle will continue.

segment.source: You can learn more by downloading the XAML data binding sample for Windows 8.1 and re-using its source code in your Windows 10 app.
segment.target: You can learn more by downloading the XAML data binding sample for Windows 8.1 and re-using its source code in your Windows 10 app.

segment.source: Random access data virtualization
segment.target: Random access data virtualization

segment.source: Random access data virtualization allows loading from an arbitrary point in the data set.
segment.target: Random access data virtualization allows loading from an arbitrary point in the data set.

segment.source: A ListView that uses random access data virtualization, used to view a collection of a million items, can load the items 100,000 – 100,050.
segment.target: A ListView that uses random access data virtualization, used to view a collection of a million items, can load the items 100,000 – 100,050.

segment.source: If the user then moves to the beginning of the list, the control loads items 1 – 50.
segment.target: If the user then moves to the beginning of the list, the control loads items 1 – 50.

segment.source: At all times, the scroll bar's thumb indicates that the ListView contains a million items.
segment.target: At all times, the scroll bar's thumb indicates that the ListView contains a million items.

segment.source: The position of the scroll bar's thumb is relative to where the visible items are located in the collection's entire data set.
segment.target: The position of the scroll bar's thumb is relative to where the visible items are located in the collection's entire data set.

segment.source: This type of data virtualization can significantly reduce the memory requirements and load times for the collection.
segment.target: This type of data virtualization can significantly reduce the memory requirements and load times for the collection.

segment.source: To enable it you need to write a data source class that fetches data on demand and manages a local cache and implements these interfaces.
segment.target: To enable it you need to write a data source class that fetches data on demand and manages a local cache and implements these interfaces.

segment.source: IList
segment.target: IList

segment.source: INotifyCollectionChanged (C\#/VB) or IObservableVectorT (C++/CX)
segment.target: INotifyCollectionChanged (C\#/VB) or IObservableVectorT (C++/CX)

segment.source: (Optionally) IItemsRangeInfo
segment.target: (Optionally) IItemsRangeInfo

segment.source: (Optionally) ISelectionInfo
segment.target: (Optionally) ISelectionInfo

segment.source: IItemsRangeInfo provides information on which items the control is actively using.
segment.target: IItemsRangeInfo provides information on which items the control is actively using.

segment.source: The items control will call this method whenever its view is changing, and will include these two sets of ranges.
segment.target: The items control will call this method whenever its view is changing, and will include these two sets of ranges.

segment.source: The set of items that are in the viewport.
segment.target: The set of items that are in the viewport.

segment.source: A set of non-virtualized items that the control is using that may not be in the viewport.
segment.target: A set of non-virtualized items that the control is using that may not be in the viewport.

segment.source: A buffer of items around the viewport that the items control keeps so that touch panning is smooth.
segment.target: A buffer of items around the viewport that the items control keeps so that touch panning is smooth.

segment.source: The focused item.
segment.target: The focused item.

segment.source: The first item.
segment.target: The first item.

segment.source: By implementing IItemsRangeInfo your data source knows what items need to be fetched and cached, and when to prune from the cache data that is no longer needed.
segment.target: By implementing IItemsRangeInfo your data source knows what items need to be fetched and cached, and when to prune from the cache data that is no longer needed.

segment.source: IItemsRangeInfo uses ItemIndexRange objects to describe a set of items based on their index in the collection.
segment.target: IItemsRangeInfo uses ItemIndexRange objects to describe a set of items based on their index in the collection.

segment.source: This is so that it doesn't use item pointers, which may not be correct or stable.
segment.target: This is so that it doesn't use item pointers, which may not be correct or stable.

segment.source: IItemsRangeInfo is designed to be used by only a single instance of an items control because it relies on state information for that items control.
segment.target: IItemsRangeInfo is designed to be used by only a single instance of an items control because it relies on state information for that items control.

segment.source: If multiple items controls need access to the same data then you will need a separate instance of the data source for each.
segment.target: If multiple items controls need access to the same data then you will need a separate instance of the data source for each.

segment.source: They can share a common cache, but the logic to purge from the cache will be more complicated.
segment.target: They can share a common cache, but the logic to purge from the cache will be more complicated.

segment.source: Here's the basic strategy for your random access data virtualization data source.
segment.target: Here's the basic strategy for your random access data virtualization data source.

segment.source: When asked for an item
segment.target: When asked for an item

segment.source: If you have it available in memory, then return it.
segment.target: If you have it available in memory, then return it.

segment.source: If you don’t have it, then return either null or a placeholder item.
segment.target: If you don’t have it, then return either null or a placeholder item.

segment.source: Use the request for an item (or the range information from IItemsRangeInfo) to know which items are needed, and to fetch data for items from your back end asynchronously.
segment.target: Use the request for an item (or the range information from IItemsRangeInfo) to know which items are needed, and to fetch data for items from your back end asynchronously.

segment.source: After retrieving the data, raise a change notification via INotifyCollectionChanged or IObservableVectorT so that the items control knows about the new item.
segment.target: After retrieving the data, raise a change notification via INotifyCollectionChanged or IObservableVectorT so that the items control knows about the new item.

segment.source: (Optionally) as the items control's viewport changes, identify what items are needed from your data source via your implementation of IItemsRangeInfo.
segment.target: (Optionally) as the items control's viewport changes, identify what items are needed from your data source via your implementation of IItemsRangeInfo.

segment.source: Beyond that, the strategy for when to load data items, how many to load, and which items to keep in memory is up to your application.
segment.target: Beyond that, the strategy for when to load data items, how many to load, and which items to keep in memory is up to your application.

segment.source: Some general considerations to keep in mind:
segment.target: Some general considerations to keep in mind:

segment.source: Make asynchronous requests for data; don't block the UI thread.
segment.target: Make asynchronous requests for data; don't block the UI thread.

segment.source: Find the sweet spot in the size of the batches you fetch items in.
segment.target: Find the sweet spot in the size of the batches you fetch items in.

segment.source: Prefer chunky to chatty.
segment.target: Prefer chunky to chatty.

segment.source: Not so small that you make too many small requests; not too large that they take too long to retrieve.
segment.target: Not so small that you make too many small requests; not too large that they take too long to retrieve.

segment.source: Consider how many requests you want to have pending at the same time.
segment.target: Consider how many requests you want to have pending at the same time.

segment.source: Performing one at a time is easier, but it may be too slow if turnaround time is high.
segment.target: Performing one at a time is easier, but it may be too slow if turnaround time is high.

segment.source: Can you cancel requests for data?
segment.target: Can you cancel requests for data?

segment.source: If using a hosted service, is there a cost per transaction?
segment.target: If using a hosted service, is there a cost per transaction?

segment.source: What kind of notifications are provided by the service when the results of a query are changed?
segment.target: What kind of notifications are provided by the service when the results of a query are changed?

segment.source: Will you know if an item is inserted at index 33?
segment.target: Will you know if an item is inserted at index 33?

segment.source: If your service supports queries based on a key-plus-offset, that may be better than just using an index.
segment.target: If your service supports queries based on a key-plus-offset, that may be better than just using an index.

segment.source: How smart do you want to be in pre-fetching items?
segment.target: How smart do you want to be in pre-fetching items?

segment.source: Are you going to try and track the direction and velocity of scrolling to predict which items are needed?
segment.target: Are you going to try and track the direction and velocity of scrolling to predict which items are needed?

segment.source: How aggressive do you want to be in purging the cache?
segment.target: How aggressive do you want to be in purging the cache?

segment.source: This is a tradeoff of memory versus experience.
segment.target: This is a tradeoff of memory versus experience.
